subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: Finally a reply
msgSnippet: Read your note about the pronunciation problem. Mr. Read found that there was difficulty in people from different countries understanding each other due to
messageBody:
Read your note about the pronunciation problem. Mr. Read found that there was difficulty in people from different countries understanding each other due to their accents. For example, we could hardly be expected to read a cockney accent in Shaws Alphabet. For written material to yourself there is no problem at all. But, if you do have a regional accent and want to correspond with people outside your region then it would be obvious that you would have to conform to the standard English pronunciation. This is a part of understanding how to use it on a national or international scale. And, it is a courtesy on your part. Checking out whether a reader could understand your particular accent would be common sense. Good luck on your studies.
Sid Tanaban

<-----Original Message----->
>
> From: rmgburke
> Sent: 8/5/2002 4:41:51 AM
> To: Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com
> Subject: [Read_Alphabet] Re: Finally a reply
>
> --- In Read_Alphabet@y..., Robert McBroom wrote:
> So the question remains, "Which authoritative accent will the QS
> dictionary accept?" The Read community has wisely been been loath
> to try to set up any accent as more acceptable than another.
>
> Yeah, that's been my problem trying to learn symbols 32-34 (y, Y, o. My problem is, for example, in
> some
> words, I can't distinguish the Ah and Ox sounds easily. Also, my
> accent is the result of a Canadian being mostly raised in Eastern
> North Carolina (mostly Piney Wood accent). So I pronounce the L in
> words like calm and talk. I can't seem to train myself to write tylk instead of tYk.
>
> If I were writing only in my personal notes (which I plan to do), it
> wouldn't be a big problem. But seeing as there's a real community of
> Read folks, I can't always just write exactly as I speak.
>
> I guess my question is: Would I still be understood and is it a
> problem?
>
> --
> /rE /bDk
>
>
